text:
I would love it!
But taking in mind that clients can use CMs from different agencies/sources that will have some high costs and considerations probably breaking things due to assumptions that we do while working with the DND. So this will end up in a very isolated ecosystem (one theme will limit most of the CMs you can use with it).
Is it bad?... just a different approach,not necessary bad.
But I believe HS vision goes on the oposite direction atm

Just asked for extendend webhooks for CMS event pages, give me a :thumbsup:!:
<https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Webhooks-for-CMS/idi-p/407147#M74094>
IMO people should not be using HS layout.css in their custom modules, and I think HS discourages that and promotes module agnostic css.

<@U6GNQ7JBU> with the rapid speed of CSS and JS innovation, I think it would theoretically be a good investment on HubSpot’s end as a way to future proof your DND editor to completely move to data attributes instead of relying on the layout.css file of the day. Then again, I am not aware of the costs of this investment of resources and it might be more expensive than I’d anticipate :shrug::skin-tone-2:

<@U7ADCU3BM> there could also be a legacy boolean added to the json file
`"legacyDND": true|false`
I was thinking more about selectors in JS/CSS that may use default/legacy HubSpot markup

At this rate - if we are going this far it might even be worth looking into making some kind of semantic markup selector as well? Maybe a choice selector on each section similar to the background and layout sections that enable a user to set the dnd-section markup from a div to an aside or section or article etc.
